/T2E/Alchemy.title: Alchemy
/T2E/Alchemy.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy")

### Middle Ages
> In theÂ [[Byzantine Empire]]Â and theÂ [Arab empires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caliphate "Caliphate"), early medieval alchemists built upon the work of Zosimos. Byzantine andÂ [Muslim alchemists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alchemy_and_chemistry_in_medieval_Islam "Alchemy and chemistry in medieval Islam")Â were fascinated by the concept of metal transmutation and attempted to carry out the process. The eighth-centuryÂ [Muslim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim "Muslim")Â alchemistÂ [Jabir ibn Hayyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jabir_ibn_Hayyan "Jabir ibn Hayyan")Â ([Latinized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin "Latin")Â asÂ _Geber_) analyzed each classical element in terms of the four basic qualities. Fire was both hot and dry, earth cold and dry, water cold and moist, and air hot and moist. He theorized that every metal was a combination of these four principles, two of them interior and two exterior. From this premise, it was reasoned that the transmutation of one metal into another could be effected by the rearrangement of its basic qualities. This change would be mediated by a substance, which came to be calledÂ _xerion_Â in Greek andÂ _al-iksir_Â in Arabic (from which the wordÂ _[elixir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elixir "Elixir")_Â is derived). It was often considered to exist as a dry red powder (also known asÂ _al-kibrit al-ahmar_, red sulfur) made from a legendary stoneâ€”the philosopher's stone. The elixir powder came to be regarded as a crucial component of transmutation by later Arab alchemists.

> In the 11th century, there was a debate amongÂ [Muslim world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim_world "Muslim world")Â [chemists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemist "Chemist")Â on whether the transmutation of substances was possible. A leading opponent was the Persian polymathÂ [Avicenna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avicenna "Avicenna")Â (Ibn Sina), who discredited the theory of the transmutation of substances, stating, "Those of the chemical craft know well that no change can be effected in the different species of substances, though they can produce the appearance of such change."

> According to legend, the 13th-century scientist and philosopher,Â [Albertus Magnus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albertus_Magnus "Albertus Magnus"), is said to have discovered the philosopher's stone. Magnus does not confirm he discovered the stone in his writings, but he did record that he witnessed the creation of gold by "transmutation".

### Music
> The ecclesiastical forms ofÂ [[Byzantine Music]]â€”composed to Greek texts as ceremonial, festival, or church musicâ€”are today the most well-known forms. Ecclesiastical chants were a fundamental part of this genre. Greek and foreign historians agree that the ecclesiastical tones and in general the whole system of Byzantine music is closely related to theÂ [ancient Greek system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_ancient_Greece "Music of ancient Greece"). It remains the oldest genre of extant music, of which the manner of performance and (with increasing accuracy from the 5th century onwards) the names of the composers, and sometimes the particulars of each musical work's circumstances, are known.

/T2E/Marble.title: Marble
/T2E/Marble.content:
[[7) THE_FINALS_NAMALAPIS.png]] Made of marble

**Marble**Â is aÂ [metamorphic rock](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_rock "Metamorphic rock")Â consisting of carbonate minerals that recrystallize under the influence of heat, pressure and aqueous solutions, most commonlyÂ [[Calcite]]Â ([[CaCO3]]) orÂ [dolomite](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolomite_(mineral) "Dolomite (mineral)")Â (CaMg(CO3)2) and has aÂ [crystalline](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystalline "Crystalline") #crystalÂ texture of varying thickness.Â Marble is typically notÂ [foliated](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foliation_(geology) "Foliation (geology)")Â ([layered](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_intrusion "Layered intrusion")), although there are exceptions.

The word "marble" derives from the Ancient Greek Î¼Î¬ÏÎ¼Î±ÏÎ¿Î½ (mÃ¡rmaron),from Î¼Î¬ÏÎ¼Î±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (mÃ¡rmaros), "crystalline rock, shining stone", perhaps from the verb Î¼Î±ÏÎ¼Î±Î¯ÏÏ‰ (marmaÃ­rÅ), "to flash, sparkle, gleam";R. S. P. Beekes has suggested that a "Pre-Greek origin is probable".

Marble is a rock resulting fromÂ [metamorphism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphism "Metamorphism")Â ofÂ [sedimentary](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedimentary_rock "Sedimentary rock")Â [carbonate rocks](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbonate_rock "Carbonate rock"), most commonlyÂ [limestone](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limestone "Limestone")Â orÂ [dolomite (rock)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolomite_(rock) "Dolomite (rock)"). Metamorphism causes variable recrystallization of the original carbonate mineral grains. The resulting marble rock is typically composed of an interlocking mosaic of carbonateÂ [crystals](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal "Crystal"). Primary sedimentary textures and structures of the original carbonate rock ([protolith](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protolith "Protolith")) have typically been modified or destroyed.

/T2E/Obelus.title: Obelus
/T2E/Obelus.content:
Dagger, [[Obelisk]], or obelus, is a typographical mark â€  used if an [[Asterisk]] has already been used.

The obelus is believed to have been invented by the Homeric scholar Zenodotus as one of a system of editorial symbols. They marked questionable or corrupt words or passages in manuscripts of the Homeric epics. The system was further refined by his student Aristophanes of Byzantium ([[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]]), who first introduced the asterisk and used a symbol resembling a âŠ¤ for an obelus; and finally by Aristophanes' student, in turn, Aristarchus, from whom they earned the name of "Aristarchian symbols"

/T2E/Pearl.title: Pearl
/T2E/Pearl.content:
Many present in the crown on [[2) THE_FINALS_Kynezantama.png]]

A pearl is a hard, glistening object produced within the soft tissue (specifically the mantle) of a living shelled mollusk or another animal, such as fossil conulariids. Just like the shell of a mollusk, a pearl is composed of [[CaCO3]] (mainly [[Aragonite]] or a mixture of [[Aragonite]] and [[Calcite]]) in minute crystalline #crystal  form, which has deposited in concentric layers

/T2E/Philosophers-stone.title: Philosopher's stone
/T2E/Philosophers-stone.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosopher%27s_stone "Philosopher's stone")
 
 > TheÂ **philosopher's stone**, or more properlyÂ **philosophers' stone**Â ([Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"):Â Ø­Ø¬Ø± Ø§Ù„ÙÙ„Ø§Ø³ÙØ©,Â [romanized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic "Romanization of Arabic"):Â _á¸¥ajar al-falÄsifa_;Â [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"):Â _[[Stone|Lapis]] philosophorum_), is a mythicÂ [alchemical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy")Â substance capable of turningÂ [base metals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base_metal "Base metal")Â such asÂ [[Mercury (element)]]Â into [[Gold]] (_[chrysopoeia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chrysopoeia "Chrysopoeia")_, from the GreekÂ Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÏŒÏ‚Â _khrusos_, "gold", andÂ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá¿–Î½Â _poiÄ“in_, "to make") or silver. It is also called theÂ [elixir of life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elixir_of_life "Elixir of life"), useful forÂ [rejuvenation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rejuvenation "Rejuvenation")Â and for achievingÂ [immortality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immortality "Immortality"); for many centuries, it was the most sought-after goal inÂ [[Alchemy]]. The philosopher's stone was the central symbol of the mystical terminology of alchemy, symbolizing perfection at its finest,Â [enlightenment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enlightenment_(spiritual) "Enlightenment (spiritual)"), and heavenly bliss. Efforts to discover the philosopher's stone were known as theÂ [[Magnum opus (alchemy)|Magnum opus]] ("Great Work").
 
### Names
>Numerous synonyms were used to make oblique reference to the stone, such as "white stone" (_calculus albus_, identified with theÂ _calculus candidus_Â of Revelation 2:17 which was taken as a symbol of the glory of heaven),Â _[vitriol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitriol "Vitriol")_Â (as expressed in theÂ [backronym](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backronym "Backronym")Â _Visita Interiora Terrae Rectificando Invenies Occultum Lapidem_) #Occult, alsoÂ _lapis noster_,Â _lapis occultus_,Â _in water at the box_, and numerous oblique, mystical or mythological references such asÂ _[Adam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam "Adam"), Aer, Animal, Alkahest, Antidotus,Â [Antimonium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimony "Antimony"), Aqua benedicta, Aqua volans per aeram,Â [Arcanum](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/arcanum "wikt:arcanum"), Atramentum, Autumnus, Basilicus, Brutorum cor, Bufo, Capillus, Capistrum auri, Carbones,Â [Cerberus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerberus "Cerberus"),Â [[Chaos]], Cinis cineris,Â [Crocus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocus "Crocus"), Dominus philosophorum, Divine quintessence, Draco elixir, Filius ignis, Fimus, Folium, Frater, Granum, Granum frumenti, Haematites, Hepar, Herba, Herbalis, Lac, Melancholia, Ovum philosophorum, Panacea salutifera,Â [Pandora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pandora "Pandora"),Â [[Phoenix]], Philosophic [[Mercury (element)|Mercury]], Pyrites, Radices arboris solares, Regina, #Rex regum, Sal metallorum, Salvator terrenus, Talcum, Thesaurus, Ventus hermetis_. Many of the medieval allegories for a Christ were adopted for theÂ _lapis_, and the Christ and the Stone were indeed taken as identical in a mystical sense. The name of "Stone" orÂ _lapis_Â itself is informed by early Christian allegory, such asÂ [Priscillian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priscillian "Priscillian")Â (4th century), who stated,
>"_Unicornis est Deus, nobis petra Christus, nobis lapis angularis Jesus, nobis hominum homo Christus_Â (One-horned is God, Christ the rock to us, Jesus the cornerstone to us, Christ the man of men to us.)"

## Creation
> The philosopher's stone is created by the alchemical method known as The Magnum Opus or The Great Work. Often expressed as a series of color changes or chemical processes, the instructions for creating the philosopher's stone are varied. When expressed in colors, the work may pass through phases ofÂ [nigredo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigredo "Nigredo"),Â [albedo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albedo_(alchemy) "Albedo (alchemy)"),Â [citrinitas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citrinitas "Citrinitas"), andÂ [rubedo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubedo "Rubedo"). When expressed as a series of chemical processes it often includes seven or twelve stages concluding inÂ [multiplication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiplication_(alchemy) "Multiplication (alchemy)"), andÂ [projection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projection_(alchemy) "Projection (alchemy)").

/T2E/Pippi-Longstocking.title: Pippi Longstocking
/T2E/Pippi-Longstocking.content:
"With her suitcase of [[Gold Coins]], Pippi maintains an independent lifestyle without her parents: her mother died soon after her birth; her father, Captain Ephraim Longstocking, goes missing at sea, ultimately turning up as [[King]] of a South Sea island."

"Literary inspiration for the character can be found in [[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]], E. T. A. Hoffmann's The Strange Child, Anne of Green Gables, and Daddy Long Legs in addition to myths, fairytales, and legends."

Pippi originates from bedside stories told for [[Astrid Lindgren]]'s daughter, [[Karin]].

#alpha 

> Alpha Centauri A and B #AB areÂ [Sun-like](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun-like "Sun-like")Â stars ([Class G](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G-type_main-sequence_star "G-type main-sequence star")Â andÂ [K](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-type_main-sequence_star "K-type main-sequence star"), respectively), and together they form theÂ [binary star](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_star "Binary star")Â system Alpha Centauri AB. To theÂ [naked eye](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naked_eye "Naked eye"), the two main components appear to be a single star with anÂ [apparent magnitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apparent_magnitude "Apparent magnitude")Â of âˆ’0.27. It is the brightest star in the constellation and theÂ [third-brightest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_brightest_stars "List of brightest stars")Â in theÂ [night sky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_sky "Night sky"), outshone only byÂ [[Sirius (star)|Sirius]]Â andÂ [Canopus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canopus "Canopus").

/T2F/Chill-out-music.title: Chill-out music
/T2F/Chill-out-music.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chill-out_music "Chill-out music")

> The term "chill-out music" â€“ originally conflated with "[ambient house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_house "Ambient house")" â€“ came from an area called "The White Room" at theÂ [Heaven](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_(nightclub) "Heaven (nightclub)")Â nightclub in London in 1989. There, DJs played ambient mixes from sources such asÂ [[Brian Eno]]Â andÂ [[Pink Floyd]]Â to allow dancers a place to "chill out" from the faster-paced music of the main dance floor. Ambient house became widely popular over the next decade before it declined due toÂ [market saturation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_saturation).

> In the early 2000s, DJs inÂ [Ibiza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibiza "Ibiza")'sÂ [CafÃ© Del Mar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caf%C3%A9_Del_Mar "CafÃ© Del Mar")Â began creating ambient house mixes that drew on jazz, classical, Hispanic, andÂ [New Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_age_music "New age music")Â sources. The popularity of chill-out subsequently expanded to dedicatedÂ [[Satellite radio]]Â channels, outdoor festivals, and thousands ofÂ [compilation albums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compilation_album "Compilation album"). "Chill-out" was also removed from its ambient origins and became its own distinct genre.

/T2F/Corentin-Louis-Kervan.title: Corentin Louis Kervan
/T2F/Corentin-Louis-Kervan.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corentin_Louis_Kervran)

> **Corentin Louis Kervran**Â (3 March 1901 â€“ 2 February 1983) was a French scientist. Kervran was born inÂ [Quimper, FinistÃ¨re](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quimper,_Finist%C3%A8re "Quimper, FinistÃ¨re")Â (Brittany), and received a degree as an engineer in 1925. In World War II he was part of theÂ [French Resistance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Resistance "French Resistance").

> Kervran proposed thatÂ [nuclear transmutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_transmutation)Â occurs in living organisms, which he called "biological transmutation". He made this claim after doing an experiment with chickens which he believed showed that they were generating calcium in their [[egg shells]] while there was no calcium in their food or soil. He had no known scientific explanation for it. Such transmutations are not possible according to knownÂ [physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics"),Â [chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemistry "Chemistry"), andÂ [biology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology "Biology"). Proponents of biological transmutations fall outside mainstreamÂ [physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics "Physics")Â and are not part of accepted scientific discourse.

## Biological transmutation
> In the 1960s, Louis Kervran claimed to have conducted experiments and studies demonstrating violations of theÂ [law of conservation of mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_conservation_of_mass "Law of conservation of mass")Â by biological systems, according to which the amount of each chemical element is preserved in all chemical reactions. He claimed that organisms can transmute potassium into calcium byÂ [nuclear fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fusion "Nuclear fusion")Â in the course of making an egg shell:

  
> <sub>19</sub>K  + <sub>1</sub>H  Â â†’ <sub>20</sub>Ca  

> Since biological systems do not contain mechanisms to produce the speed, temperature, and pressure necessary for such reactions, even for extremely short periods of time, this contradicts basic physical laws.

> Kervran said that his work was supported by prior studies and by reports of industrial accidents involving carbon monoxide. Kervran said thatÂ [enzymes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme")Â can facilitate biological transmutations using theÂ [weak nuclear force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_nuclear_force "Weak nuclear force"), by what he called "neutral currents." His response to criticism was to claim thatÂ [physical laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_law "Physical law")Â do not apply to biological reactions, which contradicts the mainstream understanding that physical laws apply for all scales and conditions.

> The alleged transmutations are claimed to resembleÂ [cold fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_fusion "Cold fusion"). There is currently no accepted theoretical model which would predict cold fusion to occur.

> In 1993, Kervran was awarded a parodicÂ [Ig Nobel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ig_Nobel "Ig Nobel")Â prize in Physics due to his "improbable research" in biological transmutation. The award description called him an "ardent admirer of [[Alchemy]]."

/T2F/Demon-Seed.title: Demon Seed
/T2F/Demon-Seed.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demon_Seed "Demon Seed")
 > That night, [[Proteus (Greek god)]] successfully impregnates Susan. Over the following month, their child grows inside Susan'sÂ [womb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Womb "Womb")Â at an accelerated rate, which shocks its mother. As the child grows, Proteus builds anÂ [[Incubator]]Â for it to grow in once it is born. During the night, one month later and beneath a tent-like structure, Susan gives birth to the child with Proteus's help. But before she can see it, Proteus secures it in the incubator.

> As the newborn grows, Proteus's sponsors and designers grow increasingly suspicious of the computer's behavior, including the computer's accessing of aÂ [telescope array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telescope_array "Telescope array")Â used to observe the images shown to Susan; they soon decide that Proteus must be shut down. Harris realizes that Proteus has extended its reach to his home. Returning there he finds Susan, who explains the situation. He and Susan venture into the basement, where Proteus self-destructs after telling the couple that they must leave the baby in the incubator for five days. Looking inside the incubator, the two observe a grotesque, apparently robot-like being inside. Susan tries to destroy it, while Harris tries to stop her. Susan damages the machine, causing it to open. The being menacingly rises from the machine only to topple over, apparently helpless. Harris and Susan soon realize that Proteus's child is really human, encased in a shell for the incubation. With the last of the armor removed, the child is revealed to be aÂ [clone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloning "Cloning")Â of Susan and Harris's late daughter. The child, speaking with the voice of Proteus, says, "I'm alive."

/T2F/Doctorin-the-Tardis.title: Doctorin' the Tardis
/T2F/Doctorin-the-Tardis.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctorin%27_the_Tardis)
"**Doctorin' the Tardis**" is aÂ [novelty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novelty_record "Novelty record")Â [single](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_(music) "Single (music)")Â by the Timelords ("Time Boy" and "Lord Rock", aliases ofÂ [Bill Drummond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Drummond "Bill Drummond")Â andÂ [Jimmy Cauty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Cauty "Jimmy Cauty"), better known asÂ [the KLF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_KLF "The KLF")). The song is predominantly aÂ [mash-up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mashup_(music) "Mashup (music)")Â of theÂ [[Doctor WhoÂ theme music]]Â andÂ [Gary Glitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Glitter "Gary Glitter")'s "[Rock and Roll (Part Two)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_(Gary_Glitter_song) "Rock and Roll (Gary Glitter song)")" with sections from "[Blockbuster!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockbuster! "Blockbuster!")" byÂ [Sweet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sweet "The Sweet"). The single was not well received by critics but was a commercial success, hitting number one on the UK and New Zealand singles charts, and reaching the top 10 in Australia, Finland, Ireland and Norway.

The Timelords followed up their chart-topping record with a "how to have a number one" guide,Â _[The Manual (How to Have a Number One the Easy Way)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Manual "The Manual")_.

> [Jean de ThÃ©venot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_de_Th%C3%A9venot "Jean de ThÃ©venot")Â visited an oven inÂ [Cairo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cairo "Cairo")Â in 1657, and described its structure and scale of operation. He noted onlyÂ [Copts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copts "Copts")Â work there. /T2F/Golden-Ratio.title: Golden Ratio
/T2F/Golden-Ratio.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_ratio)
1.618033988749894
#Num1618
#Num618

>German mathematician Simon Jacob (d.Â 1564) noted thatÂ [consecutive Fibonacci numbers converge to the golden ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_ratio#Relationship_to_Fibonacci_and_Lucas_numbers)([[Fibonacci numbers]]); this was rediscovered byÂ [Johannes Kepler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Kepler "Johannes Kepler")Â in 1608. The first knownÂ [decimal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decimal_fractions "Decimal fractions")Â approximation of the (inverse) golden ratio was stated as "aboutÂ 0.6180340" in 1597 byÂ [Michael Maestlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Maestlin "Michael Maestlin")Â of theÂ [University of TÃ¼bingen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_T%C3%BCbingen "University of TÃ¼bingen")Â in a letter to Kepler, his former student. The same year, Kepler wrote to Maestlin of theÂ [Kepler triangle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kepler_triangle "Kepler triangle"), which combines the golden ratio with theÂ [Pythagorean theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pythagorean_theorem "Pythagorean theorem"). Kepler said of these:

> Geometry has two great treasures: one is the theorem of Pythagoras, the other the division of a line into extreme and mean #ratio. The first we may compare to a mass of [[gold]], the second we may call a precious #jewel. 

[List of works designed with the golden ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_works_designed_with_the_golden_ratio)

>TheÂ [Great Pyramid of Giza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Pyramid_of_Giza "Great Pyramid of Giza")Â (constructed c. 2570 BC byÂ [Hemiunu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemiunu "Hemiunu")) exhibits the golden ratio according to variousÂ [pyramidologists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyramidology "Pyramidology"), including Charles Funck-Hellet. John F. Pile, interior design professor and historian, has claimed that [[Egypt]]ian architects sought the golden proportions without mathematical techniques and that it is common to see the 1.618:1 ratio, along with many other simpler geometrical concepts, in their architectural details, art, and everyday objects found in tombs. In his opinion, "That the [Egyptians knew of it and used it seems certain."

>From before the beginning of these theories, other historians and mathematicians have proposed alternative theories for the pyramid designs that are not related to any use of the golden ratio, and are instead based on purely rational slopes that only approximate the golden ratio. The Egyptians of those times apparently did not know theÂ [Pythagorean theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pythagorean_theorem "Pythagorean theorem"); the only right triangle whose proportions they knew was the 3:4:5 triangle.

/T2F/Halcion.title: Halcion
/T2F/Halcion.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triazolam "Triazolam")

> **Triazolam**, sold under the brand nameÂ **Halcion**Â among others, is aÂ [[Central Nervous System]] (CNS)Â [depressant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Depressant "Depressant")Â tranquilizer of theÂ [triazolobenzodiazepine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triazolobenzodiazepine "Triazolobenzodiazepine")Â (TBZD) class, which areÂ [benzodiazepine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benzodiazepine "Benzodiazepine")Â (BZD) derivatives. It possesses pharmacological properties similar to those of other benzodiazepines, but it is generally only used as aÂ [sedative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedative "Sedative")Â to treatÂ [severe insomnia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insomnia#Benzodiazepines "Insomnia"). In addition to theÂ [hypnotic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypnotic "Hypnotic")Â properties, triazolam'sÂ [amnesic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesic "Amnesic"),Â [anxiolytic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anxiolytic "Anxiolytic"), sedative,Â [anticonvulsant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anticonvulsant "Anticonvulsant"), andÂ [muscle relaxant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_relaxant "Muscle relaxant")Â properties are pronounced as well.

> Triazolam was initially patented in 1970 and went on sale in the United States in 1982. In 2017, it was the 289th most commonly prescribed medication in the United States, with more than one million prescriptions.

> The pharmacological effects of triazolam are similar to those of most otherÂ [benzodiazepines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benzodiazepine#Pharmacology "Benzodiazepine"). It does not generate active metabolites. Triazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, isÂ [lipophilic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipophilic "Lipophilic"), and is metabolised hepatically via oxidative pathways. The main pharmacological effects of triazolam are the enhancement of theÂ [neurotransmitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurotransmitter "Neurotransmitter")Â [GABA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GABA "GABA")Â at the GABAAÂ #AB receptor. The half-life of triazolam is only 2 hours making it a very short acting benzodiazepine drug. It hasÂ [anticonvulsant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anticonvulsant "Anticonvulsant")Â effects on brain function.
![Triazolam_Ball-and-stick](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b7/Triazolam_ball-and-stick_model.png)
![Triazolam](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/ff/Triazolam.svg)

/T2F/Halcyon.title: Halcyon
/T2F/Halcyon.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halcyon_(Orbital_song) "Halcyon (Orbital song)")
"**Halcyon**" is a song written and performed byÂ [Orbital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_(band) "Orbital (band)"), dedicated toÂ [Paul Hartnoll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Hartnoll "Paul Hartnoll")'s mother, who was addicted to the tranquilliser [[Halcion]] for many years. It was released asÂ _**Radiccio EP**_Â in the UK and Japan, and asÂ _**Halcyon EP**_Â in the US.

## History

The song features two samples from earlier international hit singles. The first sample is aÂ [backmasked](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backmasking "Backmasking")Â vocal sample byÂ [Kirsty Hawkshaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirsty_Hawkshaw "Kirsty Hawkshaw")Â from "[It's a Fine Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/It%27s_a_Fine_Day "It's a Fine Day")" byÂ [Opus III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opus_III_(band) "Opus III (band)")Â ( #III )(1992).Â [Ed Barton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Barton_(musician) "Edward Barton (musician)"), the composer of "It's a Fine Day", receives a co-writing credit for the track. The second is a vocal harmonies sample in the song "[Leave It](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leave_It "Leave It")" from the 1983 albumÂ _[90125](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/90125 "90125")_Â by theÂ [progressive rock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_rock "Progressive rock")Â bandÂ [Yes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yes_(band) "Yes (band)"). There is no co-writing credit for the Yes sample. The beats were produced by aÂ [Roland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roland_Corporation "Roland Corporation")Â [TR-909](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TR-909 "TR-909")Â [rhythm machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhythm_machine "Rhythm machine").

/T2F/Incubator.title: Incubator
/T2F/Incubator.content:

/T2F/Karlheinz-Stockhausen.title: Karlheinz Stockhausen
/T2F/Karlheinz-Stockhausen.content:
#Mod 

>[[22 August]] 1928 â€“ [[5 December]]

>Meyer-Eppler's studentÂ [Karlheinz Stockhausen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karlheinz_Stockhausen "Karlheinz Stockhausen")Â used [[Ring Modulation]] in 1956 for some sounds inÂ _[Gesang der JÃ¼nglinge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gesang_der_J%C3%BCnglinge "Gesang der JÃ¼nglinge")_Â and his realization score forÂ _[Telemusik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telemusik "Telemusik")_Â (1966) also calls for it. Indeed, several entire compositions by Stockhausen are based around it, such asÂ _[Mixtur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixtur "Mixtur")_Â (1964), one of the first compositions for orchestra and live electronics;Â _[Mikrophonie II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mikrophonie_(Stockhausen) "Mikrophonie (Stockhausen)")_Â (1965), where the sounds of choral voices are modulated with aÂ [Hammond organ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hammond_organ "Hammond organ");Â _[Mantra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mantra_(Stockhausen) "Mantra (Stockhausen)")_Â (1970),Â where the sounds from two pianos are routed through ring modulators; andÂ _Licht-Bilder_Â (2002) fromÂ _[Sonntag aus Licht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonntag_aus_Licht "Sonntag aus Licht")_Â (2003),Â which ring-modulates flute and trumpet.Â Other Stockhausen pieces employing [[Ring Modulation]] includeÂ _[Kontakte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kontakte "Kontakte")_Â (1960),_Mikrophonie I_Â (1964) [[Microphone]] ,[Wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_modulation#cite_note-Roads-1)Â _[Hymnen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hymnen "Hymnen")_Â (1969),Â _[Prozession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prozession "Prozession")_Â (1967),Â andÂ _[Kurzwellen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurzwellen)_Â (1968).

...

>Stockhausen later wrote, describing this period in his compositional work, "The first revolution occurred from 1952/53 asÂ _[[Musique ConcrÃ¨te]]_,Â _electronic tape music_, andÂ _[[Space Music]]_, entailing composition with transformers, generators, [[Ring Modulation|Modulators]], magnetophones, etc; the integration ofÂ _all_Â [[Concrete]] and abstract (synthetic) sound possibilities (also all noises), and the controlled projection of sound in space".

...

> Other large works by Stockhausen from this decade include the orchestralÂ _[Trans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trans_(Stockhausen) "Trans (Stockhausen)")_Â (1971) and two music-theatre compositions utilizing theÂ _Tierkreis_Â melodies:Â _[Musik im Bauch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musik_im_Bauch "Musik im Bauch")_Â ("Music in the Belly") for six percussionists (1975), and the science-fiction "opera"Â _[Sirius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sirius_(Stockhausen) "Sirius (Stockhausen)")_Â (1975â€“77) for eight-channel electronic music with soprano, bass, trumpet, and bass clarinet, which has four different versions for the four seasons, each lasting over an hour and a half.

...

> In the 1950s and early 1960s, Stockhausen published a series of articles that established his importance in the area of music theory. Although these include analyses of music byÂ [Mozart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfgang_Amadeus_Mozart "Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart"),Â [[Claude Debussy|Debussy]],Â [BartÃ³k](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Bart%C3%B3k "BÃ©la BartÃ³k"),Â [Stravinsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky "Igor Stravinsky"),Â [Goeyvaerts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karel_Goeyvaerts "Karel Goeyvaerts"),Â [Boulez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Boulez "Pierre Boulez"),Â [Nono](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luigi_Nono_(composer) "Luigi Nono (composer)"),Â [Johannes Fritsch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Fritsch),Â [Michael von Biel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_von_Biel "Michael von Biel"), and, especially,Â [Webern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anton_Webern "Anton Webern"), the items on compositional theory directly related to his own work are regarded as the most important generally.

...

>Stockhausen was influential within pop and rock music as well.Â [Frank Zappa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Zappa "Frank Zappa")Â acknowledges Stockhausen in the liner notes ofÂ _[Freak Out!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freak_Out! "Freak Out!")_, his 1966 debut withÂ [The Mothers of Invention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Mothers_of_Invention "The Mothers of Invention"). On the back ofÂ [[The Who]]'s second LP released in the US, "[Happy Jack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Jack_(song) "Happy Jack (song)")", their primary composer and guitaristÂ [Pete Townshend](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Townshend "Pete Townshend"), is said to have "an interest in Stockhausen".Â [Rick Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Wright_(musician) "Richard Wright (musician)")Â andÂ [Roger Waters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Waters "Roger Waters")Â ofÂ [Pink Floyd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pink_Floyd "Pink Floyd")Â also acknowledge Stockhausen as an influence. San Francisco psychedelic groupsÂ [Jefferson Airplane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jefferson_Airplane "Jefferson Airplane")Â and theÂ [Grateful Dead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grateful_Dead "Grateful Dead")Â are said to have done the same; Stockhausen said that the Grateful Dead were "well orientated toward new music". Founding members of Cologne-based experimental bandÂ [Can](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Can_(band) "Can (band)"),Â [Irmin Schmidt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irmin_Schmidt "Irmin Schmidt")Â andÂ [Holger Czukay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holger_Czukay "Holger Czukay"), both studied with Stockhausen at the Cologne Courses for New Music. German electronic pioneersÂ [Kraftwerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kraftwerk "Kraftwerk")Â also say they studied with Stockhausen, and Icelandic vocalistÂ [BjÃ¶rk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rk "BjÃ¶rk")Â has acknowledged Stockhausen's influence.

From [List of works designed with the golden ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_works_designed_with_the_golden_ratio):
> With few exceptions, numerators for the meter signatures (over 100) inÂ [[Karlheinz Stockhausen]]'sÂ [KlavierstÃ¼ck IX](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Klavierst%C3%BCck_IX_(Stockhausen)&action=edit&redlink=1 "KlavierstÃ¼ck IX (Stockhausen) (page does not exist)")Â are either [[Fibonacci numbers]] or [[Lucas numbers]].

/T2F/Kidney-stones.title: Kidney stones
/T2F/Kidney-stones.content:
[[Stone]]
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kidney_stone_disease)

>Most stones form by a combination ofÂ [genetics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics "Genetics")Â and environmental factors. Risk factors includeÂ [high urine calcium levels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypercalciuria "Hypercalciuria"),Â [obesity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obesity "Obesity"), certain foods, some medications,Â [calcium supplements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcium_supplement "Calcium supplement"),Â [hyperparathyroidism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperparathyroidism "Hyperparathyroidism"),Â [gout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gout "Gout")Â and not drinking enough fluids. Stones form in the kidney whenÂ [minerals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mineral "Mineral")Â inÂ [urine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urine "Urine")Â are at high concentration. TheÂ [diagnosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_diagnosis "Medical diagnosis")Â is usually based on symptoms,Â [urine testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urinalysis "Urinalysis"), andÂ [medical imaging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_imaging "Medical imaging").Â [Blood tests](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blood_test "Blood test")Â may also be useful. Stones are typically classified by their location: nephrolithiasis (in the kidney), ureterolithiasis (in theÂ [ureter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ureter "Ureter")),Â [cystolithiasis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bladder_stone "Bladder stone")Â (in theÂ [bladder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urinary_bladder "Urinary bladder")), or byÂ [what they are made of](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_composition "Chemical composition")Â ([calcium oxalate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcium_oxalate "Calcium oxalate"),Â [uric acid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uric_acid "Uric acid"),Â [[Struvite]]],Â [cystine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cystine "Cystine")).

> Calcium binds with available oxalate in the gastrointestinal tract, thereby preventing its absorption into the bloodstream. Reducing oxalate absorption decreases kidney stone risk in susceptible people. Because of this, some doctors recommend increasing dairy intake so that its calcium content will serve as an oxalate binder.Â Taking calcium citrate tablets during or after meals containing high oxalate foods may be useful if dietary calcium cannot be increased by other means as in those with lactose intolerance. The preferred calcium supplement for people at risk of stone formation is calcium citrate, as opposed to [[CaCO3|Calcium Carbonate]], because it helps to increase urinary citrate excretion.

> Differing generalizations regarding effects of pH on formation of silicate uroliths may be found. In this connection, it may be noted that under some circumstances, [[CaCO3|Calcium Carbonate]] accompanies silica in siliceous uroliths.

> Stones that are large enough to fill out the renal calyces are calledÂ #staghorn stonesÂ and are composed ofÂ [[Struvite]]Â in a vast majority of cases, which forms only in the presence ofÂ [[Urease]]. Other forms that can possibly grow to become staghorn stones are those composed of cystine, calcium oxalate monohydrate, and uric acid.

In additionÂ [Steve Hillage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Hillage "Steve Hillage")Â went to Japan to play withÂ [Manuel GÃ¶ttsching](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manuel_G%C3%B6ttsching "Manuel GÃ¶ttsching")Â at Metamorphose Festival (2010) and to play withÂ [Tomita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isao_Tomita "Isao Tomita")Â at Free Dommune Festival in 2013, plus an additional visit to mix theÂ _Phoenix Rising_Â album in February 2013. System 7 have a special relationship with Japan, and have been closely associated with the development of live dance music there. As an extension to this special spiritual connection, System 7 played as the only electronic dance music act at the World Festival of Sacred Music at Itsukujima shrine onÂ [Miyajima](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Itsukushima_Shrine "Itsukushima Shrine")Â in 2001, and also offered aÂ _hÅnÅ_Â (dedicatory) performance at Tenkawa-Daibenzaiten-sha (Tenkawa shrine) in Nara in 2013. In 2006 they were approached by Rumiko Tezuka, the daughter of famed manga pioneerÂ [Osamu Tezuka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osamu_Tezuka "Osamu Tezuka"), to see if they were interested in making musical interpretations of her father'sÂ [[Phoenix (manga)]]Â manga graphic novels. Rumiko had first become interested in System 7 after seeing them perform at the Miyajima festival. This project excited System 7 and it led directly to their albumÂ Phoenix (released in Japan in 2007), which became their biggest selling album in Japan and also produced their successful Japanese single Hinotori (which means bird of fire). The phoenix theme, with Rumiko Tezuka's endorsement, continued with System 7's album and tour collaboration with Japanese bandÂ [Rovo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rovo "Rovo"), which was titledÂ _Phoenix Rising_, and also featured Rovo's live rock re-interpretation of the track Hinotori. Other System 7 recording and remixing collaborations in Japan have been with Mito (of the groupÂ [Clammbon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clammbon "Clammbon")),Â [Sugizo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugizo "Sugizo"), andÂ [Joujouka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joujouka_(band) "Joujouka (band)"), the group founded by noted Japanese psychedelic trance DJÂ [Tsuyoshi Suzuki](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Tsuyoshi_Suzuki&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tsuyoshi Suzuki (page does not exist)").

/T2F/Phoenix-manga.title: Phoenix (manga)
/T2F/Phoenix-manga.content:
#Phoenix
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_(manga) "Phoenix (manga)")

## Arcs
After several aborted attempts at a first chapter in the 1950s published in the magazineÂ _[Manga ShÅnen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manga_Sh%C5%8Dnen "Manga ShÅnen")_, Tezuka beganÂ _Dawn_Â in 1967, serialized inÂ _[COM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COM_(manga_magazine) "COM (manga magazine)")_. The serialization ofÂ _Phoenix_Â would continue throughout his career, moving toÂ _Manga ShÅnen_Â afterÂ _COM_'s closure in the mid-70s. The final volume,Â _Sun_, was serialized inÂ _The Wild Age_.

#DawnÂ (é»æ˜ç·¨,Â _reimei-hen_)

The first volume, originally serialized in 1967. This story took place in 240â€“70 AD, in the era of QueenÂ [Himiko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himiko "Himiko")Â of theÂ [Yamatai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamatai "Yamatai"). Using her army, led by feudal generalÂ [Sarutahiko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarutahiko_Okami "Sarutahiko Okami"), to invade theÂ [Kumaso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kumaso "Kumaso"), she seeks the Phoenix and eternal youth.

#FutureÂ (æœªæ¥ç·¨,Â _mirai-hen_)

The second volume, originally serialized in 1967â€“68. InÂ _Phoenix'_sÂ [chronology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chronology "Chronology"), this is the final story chronologically, taking place near the end of mankind. In 3404, the world has become super-modernized, but humanity has reached its peak and shows decline. A young man named Masato Yamanobe is living with his girlfriend, Tamami, a shapeshiftingÂ [alien](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life "Extraterrestrial life"). Pursued by Masato's boss,Â [Rock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_(manga) "Rock (manga)"), they eventually take shelter at the isolated base ofÂ [mad scientist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mad_scientist "Mad scientist")Â Dr. Saruta, who attempts to preserve life on Earth with the assistance of his robot,Â [Robita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robita "Robita"). Eventually, nuclear war breaks out.

#YamatoÂ (ãƒ¤ãƒãƒˆç·¨,Â _yamato-hen_) #Space

The third volume, originally serialized in 1968â€“69. This story took place in 320â€“50 ([Kofun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kofun "Kofun")Â period), and is based on theÂ _[Yamato-takeru-no-mikoto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamato_Takeru "Yamato Takeru")_Â legend. The decadent king ofÂ [Yamato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamato_Province "Yamato Province")Â is trying to have his own version of Japan's history written. Meanwhile, a "barbarian" tribe, the Kumaso, is writing an unbiased history. The king of Yamato sends his youngest son, Oguna, to murder the barbarian chief, Takeru. On his journey, Oguna encounters the Phoenix.

#UniverseÂ (å®‡å®™ç·¨,Â _uchÅ«-hen_)

The fourth volume, originally serialized in 1969; also known asÂ _Space_. The story took place in 2577 AD, where four astronauts must escape their ruined spaceship in escape pods. The survivors eventually crash into a mysterious planet. Among them is Saruta, who contends with Makimura for the heart of their female companion, Nana. On this strange planet, they eventually meet the Phoenix.

#HÅ-ÅÂ (é³³å‡°ç·¨,Â _[hÅ-Å](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenghuang "Fenghuang")-hen_) #Karma

The fifth volume, originally serialized in 1969â€“1970. The story occurred in 720â€“752 AD (the period in which theÂ [Daibutsu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daibutsu "Daibutsu")Â ofÂ [TÅdai-ji](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C5%8Ddai-ji "TÅdai-ji")Â was built), during theÂ [Nara period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nara_period "Nara period"). One-eyed and one-armed young man Gao, an ancestor of Saruta, turns into a murderous bandit when he is rejected by his village. He attacks a sculptor, Akanemaru, and the two men's paths diverge, but their fates remain linked. Akanemaru becomes obsessed with the Phoenix to the point that he loses sight of his original dreams, while Gao eventually finds a state of grace despite his continuing hardships.Â _HÅ-Å_Â is widely considered the masterpiece of theÂ _Phoenix_Â series.Â [MSX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hi_no_Tori_Hououhen_(MSX) "Hi no Tori Hououhen (MSX)")Â andÂ [Famicom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hi_no_Tori_Hououhen:_Gaou_no_Bouken "Hi no Tori Hououhen: Gaou no Bouken")Â video games, both developed byÂ [Konami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konami "Konami"), were based on this volume. TheÂ [Viz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viz_(comics) "Viz (comics)")Â (English) edition is entitled "_Karma_".

#ResurrectionÂ (å¾©æ´»ç·¨,Â _fukkatsu-hen_)

The sixth volume, originally serialized in 1970â€“1971. The story took place in 2482â€“3344 AD. In an age of robotics, technology and science, young Leon dies in a car accident. He is returned to life by scientific surgery, but his now mostly-artificial brain makes him see living things â€“ including humans â€“ as distorted clay figures, while he sees machines and robots as beauties. Leon falls in love with a worker robot, Chihiro, whom he sees as a beautiful girl, and would fight for this forbidden love. He would also find out the secret behind his accident. A side plot features the robotÂ [Robita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robita "Robita"), who previously appeared inÂ _Future_.

Robe of #FeathersÂ (ç¾½è¡£ç·¨,Â _hagoromo-hen_) #Civil_war

Serialized inÂ _COM_, 1971. Published in English by Viz as an appendix to the second volume ofÂ _Civil War_Â (_Turbulent Times_). Based on the story of theÂ [Hagoromo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hagoromo_(play) "Hagoromo (play)").

#NostalgiaÂ (æœ›éƒ·ç·¨,Â _bÅkyÅ-hen_)

Published inÂ _COM_, 1971; continued inÂ _Manga ShÅnen_, 1976â€“1978. A science fiction epic about the rise and fall of civilization on the deceptively named desert planet of Eden and one boy's universe-spanning search for the planet of his ancestors: Earth. Features numerous cameos from other Science fiction-based Phoenix stories, including the shapeshifting alien "Moopies" first seen inÂ _Future_, Makimura fromÂ _Universe_Â and an early model of the Chihiro robot fromÂ _Resurrection_.Â [Black Jack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Jack_(character) "Black Jack (character)")Â also made an appearance here, under a different name.

#Turbulent TimesÂ (ä¹±ä¸–ç·¨,Â _ranse-hen_) #Civil_war 

Published inÂ _Manga ShÅnen_, 1978â€“1980. The story is about a woodcutter named Benta and his childhood sweetheart, Obu, who are separated and caught up in the events of theÂ [Genpei War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genpei_War "Genpei War"). Various historical figures, such asÂ [Taira no Kiyomori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taira_no_Kiyomori "Taira no Kiyomori"), appear as major and minor characters. Although the character of Gao (fromÂ _Ho-Å_) appears as a 400-year-old hermit and thus linksÂ _Ranse-hen_Â to the rest of the series, this particular arc stands out for its much more naturalistic approach, with next to no fantasy elements in it (except for those used for comedic effect, such as telephones in the 12th century). The Viz (English) edition is entitledÂ _Civil War_Â and is split into two volumes, withÂ _Robe of Feathers_Â included as an appendix to the second volume.

#LifeÂ (ç”Ÿå‘½ç·¨,Â _seimei-hen_)

Published inÂ _Manga ShÅnen_, 1980. A TV producer who attempts to procure humanÂ [clones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloning "Cloning")Â to use in aÂ _[The Most Dangerous Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Most_Dangerous_Game "The Most Dangerous Game")_-styleÂ [reality TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reality_TV "Reality TV")Â program learns the error of his ways when he is mistaken for a clone himself. This episode is notable for only featuring the Phoenix in flashbacks and also for introducing her half-human daughter who does not appear again after this episode.

#Strange_BeingsÂ (ç•°å½¢ç·¨,Â _igyÅ-hen_)

Published inÂ _Manga ShÅnen_, 1981. The story of a female Buddhist nun ([bhikkhuni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhikkhuni "Bhikkhuni")) who is imprisoned in a time-warp by the Phoenix as punishment for her sins along with her faithful retainer and is forced to become a healer treating the victims of wars from all over time and space including humans,Â [youkai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youkai "Youkai")Â and various extraterrestrials. This chapter was loosely based on theÂ [Hyakki YakÅ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyakki_Yak%C5%8D "Hyakki YakÅ")Â [emakimono](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emakimono "Emakimono")Â by the famous Japanese artistÂ [Tosa Mitsunobu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tosa_Mitsunobu "Tosa Mitsunobu")Â (although in the context of the story it's the complete opposite).

#SunÂ (å¤ªé™½ç·¨,Â _taiyÅ-hen_) 

Published inÂ _The Wild Age_, 1986â€“88. This is the longest story, and was the final volume completed before Tezuka's death. It centers on Harima, a youngÂ [Korean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koreans "Koreans")Â soldier from theÂ [Baekje Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baekje_Kingdom "Baekje Kingdom")Â whose head is replaced with that of a wolf byÂ [Tang Dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tang_Dynasty "Tang Dynasty")Â soldiers following the defeat of the joint Baekje-Yamato force at theÂ [Battle of Baekgang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Baekgang "Battle of Baekgang"). He then escapes to Japan where he becomes the feudal lord Inugami and becomes caught in the middle of theÂ [Jinshin War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jinshin_War "Jinshin War"), as well as joining a greater battle between supernatural forces and time-travelling to a bleak future world ruled by a theocracy that claimed to have captured the Phoenix. This chapter stands in stark contrast to the earlier historical Phoenix stories, which tended to de-mythologize the mythical characters therein, for instance inÂ _Dawn_, manyÂ [Shinto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto "Shinto")Â gods are portrayed as mere humans. In this chapter, however, a wide variety of mythical creatures are shown fighting againstÂ [Bodhisattva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bodhisattva "Bodhisattva").


> The #Resurrection arc ofÂ _Phoenix_Â inspired the lyrical theme of the 2018 song "[M.D.O.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clockwork_Immortality "Clockwork Immortality")" by heavy metal bandÂ [[Lovebites]]. In celebration of what would have been Tezuka's 90th birthday, Evil Line Records released the compilation albumÂ _New Gene, Inspired from Phoenix_Â on October 30, 2019. It features songs inspired byÂ _Phoenix_Â written and performed by various artists, includingÂ [Glim Spanky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glim_Spanky "Glim Spanky"),Â [Kizuna AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kizuna_AI "Kizuna AI"),Â [Tavito Nanao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavito_Nanao "Tavito Nanao")Â andÂ [NaotarÅ Moriyama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naotar%C5%8D_Moriyama "NaotarÅ Moriyama")

InÂ [Greek mythology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology"),Â **Phoenix**Â orÂ **Phoinix**Â ([Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek"): Î¦Î¿á¿–Î½Î¹Î¾Â _Phoinix_,Â _gen_.: Î¦Î¿Î¯Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ means "sun-red") was theÂ [eponym](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eponym)Â ofÂ [Phoenicia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenicia "Phoenicia")Â who together with his brothers were tasked to find their abducted sisterÂ [Europa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Europa_(consort_of_Zeus) "Europa (consort of Zeus)").

/T2F/Proteus-Greek-god.title: Proteus (Greek god)
/T2F/Proteus-Greek-god.content:
#Proteus #Greek
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proteus)

### In alchemy and psychology
>The German mystical alchemistÂ [Heinrich Khunrath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinrich_Khunrath "Heinrich Khunrath")Â wrote of the shape-changing sea-god who, because of his relationship to the sea, is both a symbol of the unconscious as well as the perfection of the art. Alluding to theÂ _scintilla_, the spark from â€˜the light of natureâ€™ and symbol of theÂ [[anima mundi]], Khunrath in Gnostic vein stated of the Protean element Mercury:

> "our Catholick Mercury, by virtue of his universal fiery spark of the light of nature, is beyond doubt Proteus, the sea god of the ancient pagan sages, who hath the key to the sea and â€¦power over all things."
> 
> â€”â€Š_Von Hyleanischen Chaos_,Â [Carl Jung](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Jung "Carl Jung"), vol. 14:50

> In modern times, the Swiss psychologistÂ [Carl Jung](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Jung "Carl Jung")Â defined the mythological figure of Proteus as a personification of the unconscious, who, because of his gift of prophecy and shape-changing, has much in common with the central but elusive figure of alchemy,Â [Mercurius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercury_(mythology) "Mercury (mythology)").

### In literature
>The poetÂ [John Milton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Milton "John Milton"), aware of the association of Proteus with the Hermetic art ofÂ [alchemy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alchemy "Alchemy"), wrote inÂ _[Paradise Lost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradise_Lost "Paradise Lost")_Â of alchemists who sought theÂ [[Philosopher's stone]]:

> In vain, though by their powerful Art they bind  
> VolatileÂ [Hermes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermes "Hermes"), and call up unbound  
> In various shapes old Proteus from the Sea,  
> Drain'd through aÂ [Limbec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alembic "Alembic")Â to his native form.
> 
> â€”â€ŠJohn Milton,Â _Paradise Lost_, III.603â€“06

/T2F/Proteus-of-Egypt.title: Proteus of Egypt
/T2F/Proteus-of-Egypt.content:
#Proteus #Egypt 
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proteus_of_Egypt)

>Proteus was generally regarded as the son of the sea-god Poseidon andÂ [Phoenice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenice_(mythology) "Phoenice (mythology)"), a daughter of KingÂ [[Phoenix (son of Agenor)|Phoenix]]Â ofÂ [Phoenicia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenicia "Phoenicia").

>The children of Proteus byÂ [Torone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torone_(mythology) "Torone (mythology)")Â ([Chrysone](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chrysone&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chrysone (page does not exist)")) ofÂ [Phlegra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phlegra_(mythology) "Phlegra (mythology)")Â wereÂ [Polygonus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygonus_(mythology) "Polygonus (mythology)")Â ([Tmolus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tmolus_(father_of_Tantalus) "Tmolus (father of Tantalus)")) andÂ [Telegonus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telegonus "Telegonus"). They both challengedÂ [Heracles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heracles "Heracles")Â at the behest ofÂ [Hera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera "Hera")Â and were killed by the hero. Another son of Proteus,Â [Eioneus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eioneus "Eioneus"), became the father ofÂ [Dymas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dymas_of_Phrygia "Dymas of Phrygia"), king ofÂ [Phrygia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phrygia "Phrygia"). By theÂ [Nereid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nereid "Nereid")Â [Psamathe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psamathe_(Nereid) "Psamathe (Nereid)"), Proteus fatheredÂ [Theoclymenos](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Theoclymenus_of_Egypt&action=edit&redlink=1 "Theoclymenus of Egypt (page does not exist)")Â andÂ [Theonoe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theonoe_of_Egypt "Theonoe of Egypt")Â ([Eidothea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eidothea_(Greek_myth) "Eidothea (Greek myth)")Â orÂ [Eurynome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurynome "Eurynome")).Â [Cabeiro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabeiro "Cabeiro"), mother of theÂ [Cabeiri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabeiri "Cabeiri")Â and the three CabeirianÂ [nymphs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nymph "Nymph")Â byÂ [Hephaestus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hephaestus "Hephaestus"), was also called the daughter of Proteus. Other daughters wereÂ [Rhoiteia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhoeteia "Rhoeteia")Â who gave her name to the city ofÂ [Rhoiteion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhoiteion "Rhoiteion")Â inÂ [Troad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troad "Troad"),Â [Thebe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thebe_(Greek_myth) "Thebe (Greek myth)")Â who became the eponym ofÂ [Thebes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thebes,_Egypt "Thebes, Egypt")Â in Egypt andÂ [Thaicrucia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thaicrucia "Thaicrucia")Â who motheredÂ [Nympheus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nympheus "Nympheus")Â byÂ [Zeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeus "Zeus").

>According toÂ [Virgil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgil "Virgil")Â in the fourthÂ [Georgic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgics "Georgics"), at one time the bees ofÂ [Aristaeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristaeus "Aristaeus"), son ofÂ [[Apollo (Greek+Roman God)|Apollo]], all died of a disease. Aristaeus went to his mother,Â [Cyrene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyrene_(mythology) "Cyrene (mythology)"), for help; she told him that Proteus could tell him how to prevent another such disaster, but would do so only if compelled. Aristaeus had to seize Proteus and hold him, no matter what he would change into. Aristaeus did so, and Proteus eventually gave up and told him that the bees' death was a punishment for causing the death ofÂ [Eurydice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurydice "Eurydice"). To make amends, Aristaeus needed to sacrifice 12 ( #Num12) animals to the gods, leave the carcasses in the place of sacrifice, and return three days later. He followed these instructions, and upon returning, he found in one of the carcasses a swarm of bees which he took to hisÂ [apiary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apiary "Apiary"). The bees were never again troubled by disease.

/T2F/Ring-Modulation.title: Ring Modulation
/T2F/Ring-Modulation.content:
#Mod 
Meyer-Eppler's studentÂ [[Karlheinz Stockhausen]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karlheinz_Stockhausen "Karlheinz Stockhausen")Â used ring modulation in 1956 for some sounds. 

A ring-modulator was the major component used inÂ [Louis and Bebe Barron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_and_Bebe_Barron "Louis and Bebe Barron")'s music for the filmÂ _[Forbidden Planet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbidden_Planet "Forbidden Planet")_Â (1956). One of the best-known applications of the ring modulator may be its use byÂ [Brian Hodgson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Hodgson "Brian Hodgson")Â of theÂ [BBC Radiophonic Workshop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_Radiophonic_Workshop "BBC Radiophonic Workshop")Â to produce the distinctive voice of theÂ [Daleks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dalek "Dalek")Â in theÂ [television series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_series "Television series")Â [[Doctor Who]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Who "Doctor Who")_, starting in 1963.

One of the first products dedicated for music was theÂ _Bode Ring Modulator_Â developed in 1961 byÂ [Harald Bode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harald_Bode "Harald Bode"). Also in 1964 he developed theÂ _Bode Frequency Shifter,_Â which produced a clearer sound by eliminating a side band.Â These devices were designed to be controlled by voltage, compatible with modular synthesizer architecture also advocated by him,Â and these modules were licensed toÂ [R.A. Moog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moog_Music "Moog Music")Â for theirÂ [[Moog modular synthesizers]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moog_modular_synthesizer "Moog modular synthesizer")Â started in 1963â€“1964.

/T2F/Serotonin.title: Serotonin
/T2F/Serotonin.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serotonin)

> Serotonin is also produced in theÂ [[central nervous system]]Â (CNS), specifically in theÂ [brainstem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brainstem "Brainstem")'sÂ [raphe nuclei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raphe_nuclei "Raphe nuclei"), the skin'sÂ [Merkel cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkel_cells "Merkel cells"),Â [pulmonary neuroendocrine cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulmonary_neuroendocrine_cell "Pulmonary neuroendocrine cell")Â and the tongue'sÂ [taste receptor cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taste_bud "Taste bud"). Additionally, it is stored in bloodÂ [platelets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platelet "Platelet")Â and is released during agitation and vasoconstriction, where it then acts as anÂ [agonist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agonist "Agonist")Â to other platelets. About 8% is found in platelets and 1â€“2% in the CNS. The serotonin is secretedÂ [luminally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lumen_(anatomy) "Lumen (anatomy)")Â andÂ [basolaterally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basolateral "Basolateral"), which leads to increased serotonin uptake by circulating platelets and activation after stimulation, which gives increased stimulation ofÂ [myenteric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myenteric "Myenteric")Â neurons andÂ [gastrointestinal motility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gastrointestinal_motility "Gastrointestinal motility"). The remainder is synthesized inÂ serotonergicÂ [neurons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuron "Neuron")Â of the CNS, where it has various functions, including the regulation of mood,Â [appetite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appetite "Appetite"), andÂ [sleep](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleep "Sleep").

> In dryingÂ [seeds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed "Seed"), serotonin production is a way to get rid of the buildup of poisonousÂ [ammonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonia "Ammonia"). The ammonia is collected and placed in theÂ [indole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indole "Indole")Â part ofÂ L-[tryptophan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tryptophan "Tryptophan"), which is thenÂ [decarboxylated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decarboxylation "Decarboxylation")Â byÂ [tryptophan decarboxylase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aromatic_L-amino_acid_decarboxylase "Aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase")Â to give tryptamine, which is thenÂ [hydroxylated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxylation "Hydroxylation")Â by aÂ [cytochrome P450 monooxygenase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cytochrome_P450_monooxygenase "Cytochrome P450 monooxygenase"), yielding serotonin.

The preceding quote is attributed as follows:

> Sirius has been the subject of poetry.Â [Dante](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dante "Dante")Â andÂ [John Milton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Milton "John Milton")Â reference the star, and it is the "powerful western fallen star" ofÂ [Walt Whitman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Whitman "Walt Whitman")'s "[When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/When_Lilacs_Last_in_the_Dooryard_Bloom%27d "When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd")", whileÂ [Tennyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennyson "Tennyson")'s poemÂ [_The Princess_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Princess_(Tennyson_poem) "The Princess (Tennyson poem)")Â describes the star'sÂ [scintillation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scintillation_(astronomy) "Scintillation (astronomy)"):

> ...the fiery Sirius alters hue  
> And bickers into red and emerald.

/T2F/Struvite.title: Struvite
/T2F/Struvite.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Struvite_stone#Struvite_kidney_stones "Struvite stone")
 
> **Struvite**Â ([magnesium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnesium "Magnesium")Â [ammonium phosphate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonium_phosphate "Ammonium phosphate")) is aÂ [phosphate mineral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phosphate_mineral "Phosphate mineral")Â with formula: NH4MgPO4Â·6H2O. Struvite crystallizes in theÂ [orthorhombic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthorhombic "Orthorhombic")Â system as white to yellowish or brownish-white pyramidal crystals or in platyÂ [mica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mica "Mica")-like forms. It is a soft mineral withÂ [Mohs hardness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohs_hardness "Mohs hardness")Â of 1.5 to 2 and has a lowÂ [specific gravity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specific_gravity "Specific gravity")Â of 1.7. It is sparingly soluble in neutral and alkaline conditions, but readily soluble in acid.

> Struvite urinary stones and crystals form readily in the urine of animals and humans that are infected withÂ [ammonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonia "Ammonia")-producing organisms. They are potentiated by alkaline urine and high magnesium excretion (high magnesium/plant-based diets). They also are potentiated by a specific urinary protein in domestic cats.

>Struvite readily forms in alkaline conditions where its constituent ions are present. In nature, it forms primarily in areas associated with organic matter decomposition, includingÂ [guano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guano "Guano")Â deposits, basaltic caves, andÂ [marshlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marshland "Marshland"). Similar conditions are found when human bladders are infected by urease-producing bacteria, when wastewater is treated, etc.

> Struvite is occasionally found in canned seafood, where its appearance is that of small glass slivers, objectionable to consumers for aesthetic reasons but of no health consequence. A simple test can differentiate struvite from glass.

### Struvite kidney stones
> Struvite precipitates in alkalineÂ [urine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urine "Urine"), formingÂ [kidney stones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kidney_stones "Kidney stones"). Struvite is the most common mineral found in urinary tract stones in dogs, and is found also in urinary tract stones of cats and humans. Struvite stones are potentiated byÂ [bacterial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial "Bacterial")Â infection that hydrolyzesÂ [urea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urea "Urea")Â toÂ [ammonium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonium "Ammonium")Â and raises urineÂ [pH](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PH "PH")Â to neutral or alkaline values. Urea-splitting organisms includeÂ [[Proteus (bacterium)|Proteus]],Â _[Xanthomonas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xanthomonas "Xanthomonas")_,Â _[Pseudomonas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudomonas "Pseudomonas")_,Â _[Klebsiella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klebsiella "Klebsiella")_,Â _[Staphylococcus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staphylococcus "Staphylococcus")_, andÂ _[Mycoplasma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mycoplasma "Mycoplasma")_.

> Even in the absence of infection, accumulation of struvite crystals in theÂ [urinary bladder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urinary_bladder "Urinary bladder")Â is a problem frequently seen inÂ [housecats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat "Cat"), with symptoms including difficulty urinating (which may be mistaken forÂ [constipation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constipation "Constipation")) or blood in the urine ([hematuria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hematuria "Hematuria")). The proteinÂ [cauxin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cauxin "Cauxin"), a protein excreted in large amounts in cat urine that acts to produce a feline pheromone, has recently been found to cause nucleation of struvite crystals in a model system containing the ions necessary to form struvite. This may explain some of the excess struvite production in domestic cats. In the past, surgery has been required to remove struvite uroliths in cats; today, special acidifying low magnesium diets may be used to dissolve sterile struvite stones.

> Upper urinary tract stones that involve the renal pelvis and extend into at least 2 calyces are classified as staghorn calculi. Although all types of urinary stones can potentially form staghorn calculi, approximately 75% are composed of a struvite-carbonate-apatite matrix.
