/T2F/The-KLF.title: The KLF
/T2F/The-KLF.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_KLF)
**The KLF**Â (also known asÂ **the Justified Ancients of Mu Mu**,Â **the JAMs**,Â **the Timelords** ([[Doctor Who]])Â and other names) are a British electronic band formed in London in 1987.Â [Bill Drummond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Drummond "Bill Drummond")Â (alias King Boy D) andÂ [Jimmy Cauty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Cauty "Jimmy Cauty")Â (alias Rockman Rock) began by releasingÂ [hip hop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music")-inspired andÂ [sample](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_(music) "Sampling (music)")-heavy records as the JAMs. As the Timelords, they recorded the British number-one single "[[Doctorin' the Tardis]], and documented the process of making a hit record in a bookÂ _[The Manual (How to Have a Number One the Easy Way)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Manual "The Manual")_. As the KLF, Drummond and Cauty pioneeredÂ [stadium house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stadium_house "Stadium house")Â (rave music with a pop-rock production and sampled crowd noise) and, with their 1990 LPÂ [[Chill Out (KLF album)|Chill Out]] _, theÂ [ambient house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_house "Ambient house")Â genre. The KLF released a series of international hits on their own KLF Communications record label and became the biggest selling singles act in the world in 1991.

/T2F/The-Orb.title: The Orb
/T2F/The-Orb.content:
#Band [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Orb) Performed under: | | | |---|---| |Labels|- [Big Life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Life "Big Life")
- [Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Island_Records "Island Records")
- [Badorb.com](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Badorb.com "Badorb.com")
- [Kompakt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kompakt "Kompakt")
- Malicious Damage
- [[Mercury Records\|Mercury]]
- [MCA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MCA_Records "MCA Records")| > Their influential 1991 debut albumÂ The Orb's [[Adventures Beyond the Ultraworld]] Â pioneered the UK's nascentÂ [ambient house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_house "Ambient house")Â movement,Â while its UK chart-topping follow-upÂ _[U.F.Orb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.F.Orb "U.F.Orb")_Â represented the genre's commercial peak. > > Beginning asÂ [ambient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_music "Ambient music")Â andÂ [dub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dub_music "Dub music")Â DJs inÂ [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London "London"), the Orb's early performances were inspired by electronic artists of the 1970s, most notablyÂ [[Brian Eno]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Eno "Brian Eno"),Â [Cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_(band) "Cluster (band)"), andÂ [Kraftwerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kraftwerk "Kraftwerk"). The Orb have maintained their signatureÂ #science-fiction [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_science_fiction_themes "List of science fiction themes")Â aesthetic despite numerous personnel changes, including the departure of Cauty and membersÂ [Kris Weston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kris_Weston "Kris Weston"), Andy Falconer,Â [Simon Phillips](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Phillips_(producer) "Simon Phillips (producer)"), Nick Burton, andÂ [Andy Hughes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Hughes "Andy Hughes"). Paterson has been the only permanent member, continuing to work as the Orb with Swiss-German producerÂ [Thomas Fehlmann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Fehlmann "Thomas Fehlmann"), and later, withÂ [Martin "Youth" Glover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_%22Youth%22_Glover "Martin "Youth" Glover"), bassist ofÂ [Killing Joke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Killing_Joke_(band) "Killing Joke (band)"). Paterson's unauthorised use ofÂ [other artists' works](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_(music) "Sampling (music)")Â has led to multiple disputes, most notably withÂ [Rickie Lee Jones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rickie_Lee_Jones "Rickie Lee Jones"). >During their live shows in the 1990s, the Orb performed using digital audio tape machines optimised for live mixing and sampling before switching to laptops and other digital media. Featuring colourful light shows and psychedelic imagery, their performances often incited comparisons toÂ [[Pink Floyd]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pink_Floyd "Pink Floyd"), whose guitarist,Â [David Gilmour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Gilmour "David Gilmour"), later collaborated with them on the albumÂ [[Metallic Spheres (album)]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metallic_Spheres "Metallic Spheres")_Â in 2010. >Their sixteenth studio album,Â _[Abolition of the Royal Familia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abolition_of_the_Royal_Familia "Abolition of the Royal Familia")_, was released on 27 March 2020 byÂ [Cooking Vinyl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooking_Vinyl "Cooking Vinyl"). > [Alex Paterson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Paterson "Alex Paterson")Â began his music career in the early 1980s as aÂ [roadie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadie "Roadie")Â for theÂ [post-punk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-punk "Post-punk")Â rock bandÂ [Killing Joke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Killing_Joke "Killing Joke"), for whom his childhood friendÂ [Martin "Youth" Glover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Glover "Martin Glover")Â played bass. Having left Killing Joke's employ, in 1986 Paterson became an A&R man. Paterson and Youth shared a flat inÂ [Battersea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battersea "Battersea")Â andÂ [Jimmy Cauty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimmy_Cauty "Jimmy Cauty"), Youth's former bandmate fromÂ [Brilliant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brilliant_(band) "Brilliant (band)"), was a regular visitor. Paterson and Cauty began DJing and producing music together under the name the Orb. Their first release was a 1988Â [acid house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acid_house "Acid house")Â anthem track, "Tripping on Sunshine", released on Youth's compilation albumÂ _[Eternity Project One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eternity_Project_One "Eternity Project One")_. The following year, the Orb released theÂ _[Kiss EP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiss_(The_Orb_EP) "Kiss (The Orb EP)")_, a four-trackÂ [EP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play")Â based on samples from New York City'sÂ [KISS FM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WRKS "WRKS"). It was released on Paterson and Glover's new record labelÂ [[WAU! Mr. Modo Records]] [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WAU!_Mr._Modo_Records "WAU! Mr. Modo Records"), which they created out of a desire to maintain financial independence from larger record labels. After spending a weekend of making what Paterson described as "really shit drum sounds", the duo decided to abandon beat-heavy music and instead work on music for after-hours listening by removing the percussion tracks. Paterson and Cauty began DJing in London and landed a deal for the Orb to play theÂ [chill out](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chill_out_music "Chill out music")Â room at London nightclubÂ [Heaven](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_(nightclub) "Heaven (nightclub)"). Resident DJÂ [Paul Oakenfold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Oakenfold "Paul Oakenfold")Â brought in the duo as ambient DJs for his "The Land of Oz" event at Heaven. Though the Orb's Monday night performances had only several hardcore followers initially, their chill-out room act grew popular over the course of their six-month stay to the point that the room was often packed with around 100Â people. The Orb's performances became most popular among weary DJs and clubbers seeking solace from the loud, rhythmic music of the dancefloor. The Orb built up melodies usingÂ [multitrack recordings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multitrack_recording "Multitrack recording")Â linked to multipleÂ [record decks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Record_deck "Record deck")Â and aÂ [mixer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixing_console "Mixing console"). The group incorporated many CDs, cassettes, andÂ BBC sound effects ([[BBC Radiophonic Workshop]])Â into the act, often accompanied with pieces of popular dance tracks such as "[SueÃ±o Latino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sue%C3%B1o_Latino "SueÃ±o Latino")". Though the group used a variety of samples, they avoided heavy rhythm and drums so that the intended ambient atmosphere was not disrupted. Most often, the group playedÂ [dub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dub_music "Dub music")Â and otherÂ [[Chill-out music]], which it described as ambient house for the E generation. > Throughout 1989 the Orb, along with Youth, developed aÂ [music production](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_production "Music production")Â style that incorporatedÂ [ambient music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_music "Ambient music")Â with a diverse array ofÂ [samples](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_(music) "Sampling (music)")Â and recordings. The British music press later labelled the musicÂ [ambient house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_house "Ambient house"). The culmination of the group's musical work came toward the end of the same year when they recorded a session forÂ [John Peel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Peel "John Peel")Â onÂ [[BBC Radio 1]]. The track, then known as "Loving You," was largely improvisational and featured a wealth of sound effects and samples fromÂ [science fiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction")Â radio plays, nature sounds, andÂ [[Minnie Riperton]] 's "[[Lovin' You]]". For its release as a single on the record labelÂ [Big Life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Life "Big Life"), the Orb changed the title to "[[A Huge Ever Growing Pulsating Brain That Rules from the Centre of the Ultraworld]]. Upon the single's release, Riperton's management forced Big Life to remove the unlicensed Riperton sample, ensuring that only the initial first-week release of the single contained the original vocals of Minnie Riperton; subsequent pressings used vocals from a sound-alike. Despite its running time of 22 minutes, the sample-laden single reached #78 on theÂ [British singles charts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UK_singles_chart "UK singles chart"). Soon thereafter, the Orb were commissioned byÂ [Dave Stewart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_A._Stewart "David A. Stewart")Â to remix his top-20 single "[Lily Was Here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lily_Was_Here "Lily Was Here")". The group obliged and were soon offered several more remix jobs from artists includingÂ [Erasure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erasure "Erasure")Â andÂ [[System 7 (band)]]. ... > Following the split, Paterson began working with Youth on the track "[[Little Fluffy Clouds]]". The group incorporated samples fromÂ [Steve Reich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Reich "Steve Reich")'sÂ _[Electric Counterpoint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_Counterpoint "Electric Counterpoint")_. The signature of the piece centres around the repeated phrases sampled from the voice of singer/songwriterÂ [Rickie Lee Jones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rickie_Lee_Jones "Rickie Lee Jones"), her spaced-out childlike ramble taken from a promotional CD released by Geffen Records for her 1989 album,Â _[Flying Cowboys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_Cowboys "Flying Cowboys")_. In it she muses on the picturesque images of clouds from her Arizona childhood. ... > Also in the summer of 1994 the Orb provided music for The Jupiter Collision, the BBC's brief info series about the [[Comet Shoemakerâ€“Levy 9|Shoemaker-Levy]] comet.

/T2F/Titans.title: Titans
/T2F/Titans.content:
#Greek
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titan_(mythology) "Titan (mythology)")
> InÂ [Greek mythology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology"), theÂ **Titans**Â ([Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language "Ancient Greek language"):Â Î¿á¼± Î¤á¿‘Ï„á¾¶Î½ÎµÏ‚,Â _hoi TÄ«tÃ¢nes_,Â [singular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_number "Grammatical number"):Â á½ Î¤á¿‘Ï„á¾±ÌÎ½, -Î®Î½,Â _ho TÄ«tÃ¢n_) were the pre-Olympian gods. According to theÂ _[Theogony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theogony "Theogony")_Â ofÂ [Hesiod](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hesiod "Hesiod"), they were the twelve children of the primordial parentsÂ [Uranus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uranus_(mythology) "Uranus (mythology)")Â (Sky) andÂ [Gaia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaia "Gaia")Â (Earth), with six male Titansâ€”[Oceanus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceanus "Oceanus"),Â [Coeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coeus "Coeus"),Â [Crius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crius "Crius"),Â [Hyperion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperion_(Titan) "Hyperion (Titan)"),Â [Iapetus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iapetus "Iapetus"), andÂ [Cronus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cronus "Cronus")â€”and six female Titans, called theÂ **Titanides**Â or "Titanesses" (Î±á¼± Î¤á¿‘Ï„á¾±Î½á¿ÌÎ´ÎµÏ‚,Â _hai TÄ«tÄnÃ­des_)â€”[Theia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theia "Theia"),Â [Rhea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhea_(mythology) "Rhea (mythology)"),Â [Themis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Themis "Themis"),Â [Mnemosyne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mnemosyne "Mnemosyne"),Â [Phoebe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoebe_(Titaness) "Phoebe (Titaness)"), andÂ [Tethys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tethys_(mythology) "Tethys (mythology)"). Cronus mated with his older sister Rhea, who then bore the first generation of Olympians: the six siblingsÂ [Zeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeus "Zeus"),Â [Hades](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hades "Hades"),Â [Poseidon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon"),Â [Hestia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hestia "Hestia"),Â [Demeter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demeter "Demeter"), andÂ [Hera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera "Hera"). Certain descendants of the Titans, such asÂ [Prometheus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus "Prometheus"),Â [Atlas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlas_(mythology) "Atlas (mythology)"),Â [Helios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helios "Helios"), andÂ [Leto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leto "Leto"), are sometimes also called Titans.

> The Titans were the former gods: the generation of gods preceding theÂ [Olympians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelve_Olympians#Olympians "Twelve Olympians"). They were overthrown as part of the Greek succession myth, which tells how Cronus seized power from his father Uranus and ruled the cosmos with his fellow Titans before being in turn defeated and replaced as the ruling pantheon of gods by Zeus and the Olympians in a ten-year war called "theÂ [Titanomachy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titanomachy "Titanomachy")" (á¼¡ Î¤á¿‘Ï„á¾±Î½Î¿Î¼á¾°Ï‡á¿Ìá¾± Î¤á¿‘Ï„á¾±Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Ï‡Î¯á¾±Â _hÄ“ TÄ«tÄnomakhÃ­Ä_). As a result of this war, the vanquished Titans were banished from the upper world and held imprisoned under guard inÂ [Tartarus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tartarus "Tartarus"), although apparently some Titans were allowed to remain free.

/T2F/Twelve-Olympians.title: Twelve Olympians
/T2F/Twelve-Olympians.content:
#Num12
#Greek
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelve_Olympians)
InÂ [ancient Greek religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_religion "Ancient Greek religion")Â andÂ [mythology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology"), theÂ **twelve Olympians**Â are the majorÂ [deities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deity "Deity")Â of theÂ [Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology")Â [pantheon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantheon_(religion) "Pantheon (religion)"), commonly considered to beÂ [Zeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeus "Zeus"),Â [Poseidon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon"),Â [Hera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera "Hera"),Â [Demeter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demeter "Demeter"),Â [Aphrodite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aphrodite "Aphrodite"),Â [Athena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena "Athena"),Â [Artemis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemis "Artemis"),Â [[Apollo (Greek+Roman God)|Apollo]],Â [Ares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ares "Ares"),Â [Hephaestus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hephaestus "Hephaestus"),Â [Hermes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermes "Hermes"), and eitherÂ [Hestia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hestia "Hestia")Â orÂ [Dionysus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dionysus "Dionysus"). They were calledÂ _Olympians_Â because, according to tradition, they resided onÂ [Mount Olympus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Olympus "Mount Olympus").

Besides the twelve Olympians, there were many other cultic groupings of twelve gods.

The Olympians were a race ofÂ [deities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deity "Deity"), primarily consisting of a third and fourth generation of immortal beings, worshipped as the principal gods of the GreekÂ [pantheon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantheon_(religion) "Pantheon (religion)")Â and so named because of their residency atopÂ [Mount Olympus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Olympus "Mount Olympus"). They gained their supremacy in a ten-year-longÂ [war of gods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titanomachy "Titanomachy"), in whichÂ [Zeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeus "Zeus")Â led his siblings to victory over the previous generation of ruling immortal beings, theÂ [[Titans]], children of theÂ [primordial deities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_primordial_deities "Greek primordial deities")Â [Uranus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uranus_(mythology) "Uranus (mythology)")Â andÂ [Gaia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaia "Gaia").

/T2F/White-Noise-band.title: White Noise (band)
/T2F/White-Noise-band.content:
#Band
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Noise_(band))
> White Noise are an English experimental electronic music band formed in London in 1968, after American-born David Vorhaus, a classical bass player with a background in physics and electronic engineering, attended a lecture by Delia Derbyshire, a sound scientist at the [[BBC Radiophonic Workshop]]. Derbyshire and Brian Hodgson, then both former members of electronic music project Unit Delta Plus, joined Vorhaus to form the band.

>An Electric Storm
In June 1969 White Noise released the groundbreaking album An Electric Storm on Island Records. The album was created using a variety of tape manipulation techniques, and used the first British synthesizer, the EMS Synthi VCS3. Amongst many oddities, the first track on the album, Love Without Sound ( #love ) , employed sped-up tape edits of Vorhaus playing the double bass to create violin and cello sounds. Although not initially commercially successful for Island, the album is now considered an important and influential album in the development of electronic music, namechecked by contemporary artists like [[The Orb]] and Julian Cope, influencing contemporary acts such as Broadcast, [[Add N to (X)]], and Secret Chiefs 3. Peter Kember of Spacemen 3 included 'Firebird' on his 2004 curated compilation Spacelines.


#III 
> _White Noise 2-III-IV-V 
Following the departure of Derbyshire and Hodgson, to pursue other projects, Vorhaus released a second album, the largely instrumentalÂ _White Noise 2 - Concerto for Synthesizer_Â onÂ [Virgin Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Records "Virgin Records")Â in 1974. It was recorded in his own studio inÂ [Camden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Borough_of_Camden "London Borough of Camden"), North London. The album further utilized theÂ [EMS VCS 3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EMS_VCS_3 "EMS VCS 3"), as well as prototypeÂ [sequencers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_sequencer "Music sequencer"). A third album, the single track ' #space fantasy'Â _White Noise III - Re-Entry_Â was released by Pulse Records in 1980. A further two albums were released, the atmosphericÂ _White Noise IV - Inferno_Â (AMP Music) (1990) incorporated the use of samples, andÂ _White Noise V - Sound Mind_Â (AMP Music; 2000), an experiment in what Vorhaus called "[dark ambient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_ambient "Dark ambient")".

/T2F/anima-mundi.title: anima mundi
/T2F/anima-mundi.content:
[wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anima_mundi "Anima mundi")
 #Greek
> TheÂ _**anima mundi**_Â ([Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek"):Â ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´ ÎºÏŒÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï…,Â _psychÃ¨ kÃ³smou_) orÂ **world soul**Â is, according to several systems of thought, an intrinsic connection between all living beings, which relates to the world in much the same way as theÂ [soul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soul_(spirit) "Soul (spirit)")Â is connected to the human body.

> Although the concept of theÂ _anima mundi_Â originated inÂ [classical antiquity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical antiquity"), similar ideas can be found in the thoughts of later European philosophers such as those ofÂ [Baruch Spinoza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baruch_Spinoza "Baruch Spinoza"),Â [Gottfried Leibniz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Leibniz "Gottfried Leibniz"),Â [Immanuel Kant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immanuel_Kant "Immanuel Kant"),Â [Friedrich Schelling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Schelling "Friedrich Schelling"), andÂ [Georg W.F. Hegel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georg_Wilhelm_Friedrich_Hegel "Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel")Â (particularly in his concept ofÂ _[Weltgeist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weltgeist "Weltgeist")_).


### Platonism
> Further information:Â [Neoplatonism Â§Â The world-soul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism#The_world-soul "Neoplatonism"), andÂ [Timaeus (dialogue)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timaeus_(dialogue) "Timaeus (dialogue)")

> [[Plato]]Â adhered to this idea, identifying the universe as a living being:

> Thus, then, in accordance with the likely account, we must declare that thisÂ [Cosmos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmos "Cosmos")Â has verily come into existence as a Living Creature endowed with soul and reason [...] a Living Creature, one and visible, containing within itself all the living creatures which are by nature akin to itself.
> 
> â€”â€Š[Plato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plato "Plato"),Â _[Timaeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timaeus_(dialogue) "Timaeus (dialogue)")_Â 30bâ€“d, translated by W.R.M. Lamb

> Plato'sÂ _Timaeus_Â describes this living cosmos as being built by theÂ [demiurge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demiurge "Demiurge")Â constructed as to beÂ [self-identical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_identity "Law of identity")Â andÂ [intelligible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligibility_(philosophy) "Intelligibility (philosophy)")Â to reason, according to aÂ [rational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rationalism "Rationalism")Â pattern expressed inÂ [mathematical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical "Mathematical")Â principles and Â [[Pythagorean interval|Pythagorean ratio]]s (describing the structure of the cosmos, and particularly the motions of the sevenÂ [[classical planets]])

#### Manichaeism
> InÂ [Manichaeism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manichaeism "Manichaeism"), theÂ _anima mundi_Â was also called the Light Soul and the Living Soul ([Middle Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Persian_language "Middle Persian language"):Â grÄ«w zÄ«ndag), contrasting it with matter, which was associated with lifelessness and death and within which theÂ _anima mundi_Â was imprisoned. TheÂ _anima mundi_Â was personified as theÂ [Suffering Jesus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesus_in_Manichaeism#Jesus_the_Suffering "Jesus in Manichaeism")Â (__Jesus patibilis__) who, like theÂ [historical Jesus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesus_in_Manichaeism#Jesus_the_Messiah "Jesus in Manichaeism"), was depicted as being crucified ([[Crucifix]]) in the world. ThisÂ _mystica cruxificio_Â was present in all parts of the world, including the skies, soil, and trees, as expressed in theÂ [Coptic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coptic_language)Â [Manichaean psalms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manichaean_psalms "Manichaean psalms").

### [[Hermeticism]]
> The concept of theÂ _anima mundi_Â is present in the works ofÂ [hermetic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermeticism "Hermeticism")Â philosophers likeÂ [Paracelsus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracelsus "Paracelsus")Â andÂ [Robert Fludd](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Fludd "Robert Fludd").

## Parallels in eastern philosophy
> Similar concepts inÂ [eastern philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_philosophy "Eastern philosophy")Â include theÂ _[brahman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahman "Brahman")_,Â _[purusha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purusha "Purusha")_, andÂ _[paramatman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramatman "Paramatman")_Â ofÂ [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism"), andÂ _[qi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qi "Qi")_Â in the ChineseÂ [School of Naturalists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_of_Naturalists "School of Naturalists"),Â [[Taoism]], andÂ [Neo-Confucianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Confucianism "Neo-Confucianism").
